awd_titl_txt: WRF: Collaborative Research: Extended-range forecasts of atmospheric rivers for adaptive management of flood risk, water supply, and environmental flows in California
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop ways to improve the robustness of human and environmental water supplies in California and similar regions with highly variable climates. Adaptive control policies that explicitly account for uncertainty in forecasts of extreme storm events will be designed. This work will explicitly tailor water system operations for regional storm track patterns and associated forecast errors for those storm types. Expected outcomes include three major scientific advancements: 1) characterization and modeling of spatial and temporal uncertainty in extended-range forecasts of cold-season precipitation, temperature, and floods at different locations and lead times 2) this improved knowledge of forecast error structure will be coupled with computational approaches for water resources control policy design to develop adaptive policies that are robust to forecast uncertainty; 3) determination of how forecast-informed control policies should be designed for long-term climate uncertainty represented by decadal-scale droughts and floods. Through these outcomes, this work will support a shift toward integrating state-of-the-art climate information with decision-making in the water sector of California, and findings from this work will be transferable to other semi-arid regions with similar flood regimes. 

This work will enable extensive interactions and technology transfer with key stakeholders in water management agencies in California throughout the project to promote the translation of research findings and methods into practice. All software and data analysis performed for this project will be open source and hosted on GitHub, enabling researchers around the world to reproduce and extend the project's findings. These software tools will be designed to support analyses on desktop computers as well as high-performance computing clusters, including NSF XSEDE resources, to support a range of decision-making processes. The team will advance graduate and undergraduate education in the key areas of data science and software design, identified in recent National Academy reports as critical issues for scientific reproducibility and workforce preparedness. These education expansions include of the PIs' statistics courses at Cornell and water resources engineering courses at UC Davis, incorporating simplified data analysis and modeling tasks from this project. Educational developments will be shared broadly through the ASCE Task Committee on Education (ECSTATIC).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The climate in California is very variable, marked by prolonged droughts that are often punctuated by extreme floods. Efficient management of surface reservoirs and groundwater aquifers is critical to buffer this variability, but current system operations in the region are very conservative and do not formally incorporate extended range (1-14 day) forecasts of precipitation and streamflow, primarily because they haven?t been proven accurate enough to ensure their safe use prior to large floods. This research developed statistical forecast and hydrologic modeling tools to test whether forecasts could be used safely to improve water supply security in California without increasing flood risk. To achieve this, we undertook four major projects, each with their own key outcomes.

First, we examined past forecasts of heavy precipitation events and the storms that deliver them (atmospheric rivers) from numerical weather prediction models. We investigated whether there were any systematic patterns in how the forecasts incorrectly predicted heavy precipitation events. The outcome of this project showed that there were indeed systematic patterns of forecast error, and at longer lead times, these patterns were often related to whether a storm was completely missed by a forecast or its landfall put in the wrong place along the West Coast.

In the second project, we developed a statistical model of forecast errors, both for precipitation but also for temperature and streamflow variables. This statistical model was able to replicate the nuanced behavior of forecast errors across lead times, variables, and locations. Importantly, this model can be used to sample new (?synthetic?) forecast errors that are statistically plausible but were never actually observed. The synthetic errors can then be added to long records of observed streamflow or precipitation and temperature that extend back to the early twentieth century, creating records of synthetic forecasts that extend well before the period when archived forecasts are available. When coupled with models of reservoir systems, these synthetic forecasts allow water managers to test how well forecast-informed reservoir operations perform during past extreme events, helping to build confidence in forecast-based operations. Thus, a key outcome of this project was the development of technology that can help to assess the safety of forecast-based reservoir operations.  This technology has been shared and is being used by a team of state and federal government agencies exploring the question of forecast use for reservoir operations in California and elsewhere.

In the third and fourth projects, we developed new statistical approaches to hydrologic modeling and record extension based on tree-ring records, with the goal of recreating long hydrologic records that can be used to further test the viability of forecast-informed reservoir operations. The major outcome of these projects was the development of techniques that can create synthetic data used to extensively test the safety of reservoir operations and the use of forecasts, well beyond testing that can be done only using historically observed data. 

Ultimately, the outcomes of this entire project support a transformative shift towards integrating state-of-the-art climate information into decision-making in the water sector of California. This contribution is critically important given the growing stress that droughts and floods have placed on the state and the Western US more broadly over recent decades. Furthermore, the work under this project was conducted by a doctoral student who received extensive training in techniques of statistical hydrology and water resources management, thus helping to train the next generation of water professionals.
